alert.note: Alert for Coshocton (Ohio) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pittsburgh (Western Pennsylvania and East Central Ohio)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 25 at 11:14AM EDT until March 28 at 9:30AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio... Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County. .Due to rainfall over the last couple of days, the Muskingum River below Coshocton has risen into Minor Flood. It will crest early Sunday in Minor Flood.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at weather.gov/pbz. OHC031-260315- /O.EXT.KPBZ.FL.W.0003.230325T1541Z-230328T1330Z/ /CSHO1.1.ER.230325T1541Z.230326T1800Z.230328T0730Z.NO/ 1114 AM EDT Sat Mar 25 2023 ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TUESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Muskingum River at Coshocton. * WHEN...Until late Tuesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Water reaches low lying areas between Tuscarawas and Walhonding Rivers just upstream of the confluence of the two rivers. At 15.0 feet, Low areas are flooded and water reaches a few homes along Route 16 south of Coshocton and along County Route 1A north of Coshocton. At 16.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect the Lake Park area along the Walhonding River and begins backwater flooding along Mill Creek north of Lake Park and along Route 83. Flood waters will begin to enter yards in low-lying areas along County Route 1A. At 18.0 feet, Moderate flooding occurs along County Route 1A and lower areas along Route 16 south. Widespread flooding occurs from the Lake Park area south to near the intersection of Routes 83 and 36. Homes around North Water Street in Coshocton floods. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM EDT Saturday the stage was 14.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 16.3 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 18.0 feet on 03/20/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
